title: Research Hub: Style & Layout Brief
text:
Design Vision Document A comprehensive guide to the visual identity, layout structure, and user experience for a modern policy-research institute website.



This brief establishes the design direction for a research hub website that communicates credibility, expertise, and modern professionalism. The aesthetic balances academic seriousness with contemporary eleganceâ€”approachable enough for media and policymakers, rigorous enough for economists and researchers.
Core Design Principles: - Clarity over complexity - Authority without stuffiness - Timeless elegance, not fleeting trends - Content as the hero

Success/Highlight

#0A7B7B
Optional secondary accent for variety






The palette draws from institutional designâ€”think established universities, respected journals, serious think tanks. The Oxford Blue accent conveys trust and intellectual depth without the coldness of pure navy. The warm off-white base prevents the clinical sterility common in academic sites while maintaining professionalism.
Usage Rules: - Accent color appears sparingly: buttons, links, active states, key highlights - Never more than 15% of any given page should be accent-colored - Text always maintains high contrast ratios (WCAG AA minimum)







/* Primary: Headings & Display */
font-family: 'Inter', 'SF Pro Display', -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', sans-serif;

/* Body Text */
font-family: 'Inter', 'SF Pro Text', -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', sans-serif;

/* Monospace (code, data) */
font-family: 'JetBrains Mono', 'SF Mono', 'Fira Code', monospace;

Visual Treatment:

Background Option A â€” Subtle Gradient:

Soft gradient from #FAFAF8 (top) to #E8EEF4 (bottom)
Clean, minimal, lets typography breathe

Background Option B â€” Abstract Geometric:

Faint geometric pattern (interconnected nodes, subtle grid, flowing lines)
8â€“12% opacity maximum
Suggests networks, data, interconnection without being literal

Background Option C â€” Photography (if used):

Desaturated, high-contrast architectural or abstract image
Dark overlay gradient (60â€“70% opacity at text area)
Never stock photos of â€œbusiness people shaking handsâ€

.cta-primary {
  background-color: #1E3A5F;
  color: #FFFFFF;
  padding: 16px 32px;
  border-radius: 4px;  /* Subtle rounding, not pill-shaped */
  font-weight: 600;

}

.cta-primary:hover {

  transform: translateY(-2px);
  box-shadow: 0 4px 12px rgba(30, 58, 95, 0.25);
}

Card Specifications:
.research-card {
  background: #FFFFFF;
  border: 1px solid #E8E8E6;
  border-radius: 8px;
  padding: 28px;
  transition: all 0.25s ease;
}

.research-card:hover {
  border-color: #1E3A5F;
  box-shadow: 0 8px 24px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.08);
  transform: translateY(-4px);
}

.card-category {
  font-size: 12px;
  font-weight: 600;
  text-transform: uppercase;
  letter-spacing: 0.1em;
  color: #1E3A5F;
  margin-bottom: 12px;
}

.card-title {
  font-size: 20px;
  font-weight: 600;
  line-height: 1.3;
  color: #2D3436;
  margin-bottom: 12px;
}

.card-excerpt {
  font-size: 15px;
  line-height: 1.6;
  color: #636E72;
  margin-bottom: 16px;
}

.card-meta {
  font-size: 13px;
  color: #636E72;
}

Primary Button: - Background: Oxford Blue (#1E3A5F) - Text: White, 15px, semi-bold - Padding: 14px 28px (comfortable touch target) - Border-radius: 4px (not rounded pill) - Hover: Darker shade + subtle lift + shadow
Secondary Button: - Background: Transparent - Border: 2px solid Oxford Blue - Text: Oxford Blue, 15px, semi-bold - Hover: Fill with Oxford Blue, text turns white
Ghost/Text Button: - No background or border - Text: Oxford Blue with subtle arrow (â†’) - Hover: Underline appears

Padding: 4px 10px
Border-radius: 4px
Used for: Categories, topics, document types

Border-radius: 4px
Padding: 12px 16px

Background: White









12-column grid on desktop (max-width: 1200px, centered)
24px gutters between columns
Content max-width: 720px for long-form text (optimal reading width)
Full-bleed sections break out of max-width where appropriate

Hero: 80â€“120px padding top/bottom
Major sections: 64â€“80px vertical padding
Cards within sections: 24px gaps
Paragraphs: 24px margin-bottom








If using photos, choose: - Abstract architectural details (columns, light through windows) - Conceptual imagery (stacked books, documents, data visualizations) - Professional environments (libraries, research settingsâ€”NOT staged) - Desaturated, muted tones that match the palette
Never use: - Cheesy stock photos (handshakes, pointing at charts, diverse groups looking at laptops) - Overly saturated or processed images - Literal policy imagery (Capitol buildings, gavelsâ€”too on-the-nose)



Consider a signature graphic style using: - Thin-line geometric patterns (nodes, grids, flowing lines) - Subtle data-visualization motifs (abstract charts, graph patterns) - Low-opacity textures for section backgrounds




Style: Line icons (outlined, not filled)
Stroke weight: 1.5â€“2px consistent
Size: 24px standard, 20px in navigation
Color: Slate Grey default, Oxford Blue on hover/active
Source: Feather Icons, Phosphor Icons, or custom set

Width
Behavior

<768px

Tablet
768â€“1024px

Desktop
1024â€“1440px

>1440px
Max-width container, centered







Hero headline: 32â€“36px (scaled down)
Hero height: Auto (content determines)
Cards: Full-width, stacked vertically
Navigation: Hamburger menu with slide-out drawer
Buttons: Full-width on mobile forms
Footer: Single-column stacked layout









Subtle, purposeful animations only
Never distracting or playful
Enhances understanding of state changes




Hover States:
transition: all 0.2s ease;

Buttons: Color darkens, slight lift (translateY: -2px), shadow appears
Cards: Border color changes, lift effect, shadow deepens
Links: Underline appears or color shifts

Page Load: - Hero content fades in with slight upward motion (0.4s ease) - Cards stagger in subtly (0.1s delay each) - No spinning loadersâ€”use skeleton screens if needed
Scroll Effects: - Navigation shadow appears after scroll threshold - Subtle parallax on hero background (optional, tasteful)






Color contrast ratios meet WCAG AA (4.5:1 for body text, 3:1 for large text)
All interactive elements have visible focus states
Alt text on all images
Semantic HTML structure (proper heading hierarchy)
Keyboard navigation works throughout
Form labels properly associated with inputs
Skip-to-content link for screen readers
Responsive text (scales with user preferences)

When someone lands on this site, they should immediately sense:

Authority â€” This is a serious institution with serious research
Clarity â€” The content is accessible, well-organized, easy to navigate
Modernity â€” Contemporary design sensibility, not a dusty academic relic
Trust â€” Clean, professional presentation signals credibility
Focus â€” The research is the star; design supports, never distracts

The design should age gracefully. In 5 years, it should still feel currentâ€”because it relies on timeless principles (clarity, whitespace, strong typography) rather than trendy effects.

title: Research Hub: Style & Layout Brief
text:
This brief establishes the design direction for a research hub website that communicates credibility, expertise, and modern professionalism. The aesthetic balances academic seriousness with contemporary eleganceâ€”approachable enough for media and policymakers, rigorous enough for economists and researchers.
Core Design Principles: - Clarity over complexity - Authority without stuffiness - Timeless elegance, not fleeting trends - Content as the hero

Success/Highlight
Teal Accent
#0A7B7B
Optional secondary accent for variety






The palette draws from institutional designâ€”think established universities, respected journals, serious think tanks. The Oxford Blue accent conveys trust and intellectual depth without the coldness of pure navy. The warm off-white base prevents the clinical sterility common in academic sites while maintaining professionalism.
Usage Rules: - Accent color appears sparingly: buttons, links, active states, key highlights - Never more than 15% of any given page should be accent-colored - Text always maintains high contrast ratios (WCAG AA minimum)

title: Research Hub: Style & Layout Brief
text:
If using photos, choose: - Abstract architectural details (columns, light through windows) - Conceptual imagery (stacked books, documents, data visualizations) - Professional environments (libraries, research settingsâ€”NOT staged) - Desaturated, muted tones that match the palette
Never use: - Cheesy stock photos (handshakes, pointing at charts, diverse groups looking at laptops) - Overly saturated or processed images - Literal policy imagery (Capitol buildings, gavelsâ€”too on-the-nose)



Consider a signature graphic style using: - Thin-line geometric patterns (nodes, grids, flowing lines) - Subtle data-visualization motifs (abstract charts, graph patterns) - Low-opacity textures for section backgrounds




Style: Line icons (outlined, not filled)
Stroke weight: 1.5â€“2px consistent
Size: 24px standard, 20px in navigation
Color: Slate Grey default, Oxford Blue on hover/active
Source: Feather Icons, Phosphor Icons, or custom set

text:

Never distracting or playful
Enhances understanding of state changes

transition: all 0.2s ease;

Links: Underline appears or color shifts

Scroll Effects: - Navigation shadow appears after scroll threshold - Subtle parallax on hero background (optional, tasteful)

text:

title: Research Hub: Style & Layout Brief
Research Hub: Style & Layout Brief
text:
When someone lands on this site, they should immediately sense:

Authority â€” This is a serious institution with serious research
Clarity â€” The content is accessible, well-organized, easy to navigate
Modernity â€” Contemporary design sensibility, not a dusty academic relic
Trust â€” Clean, professional presentation signals credibility
Focus â€” The research is the star; design supports, never distracts

The design should age gracefully. In 5 years, it should still feel currentâ€”because it relies on timeless principles (clarity, whitespace, strong typography) rather than trendy effects.

Document Version: 1.0 Created: December 2025

title: Privacy Policy
text:
Last updated: December 3, 2025



This Research Hub website is a personal academic project website. We do not collect, store, or process any personal information from visitors.




We do not use cookies
We do not track visitors
We do not collect email addresses or contact information
We do not use analytics services




This website contains links to external resources including:

Google Drive
Google Docs
GitHub repositories
Quarto publishing platform

These external services have their own privacy policies. We recommend reviewing their policies if you choose to visit those sites.



We may update this privacy policy from time to time. Any changes will be posted on this page with an updated revision date.



If you have questions about this privacy policy, please contact:
Myles Owens Email: maowens@stanford.edu

title: Research Hub - Project Documentation
text:
This is a Quarto-based research website called â€œresearch_hubâ€. Quarto is an open-source scientific and technical publishing system that allows you to create dynamic content with R, Python, Julia, and other languages.



research_hub/
â”œâ”€â”€ _quarto.yml                    # Main Quarto configuration file
â”œâ”€â”€ index.qmd                      # Homepage content
â”œâ”€â”€ github.qmd                     # GitHub page content
â”œâ”€â”€ styles.css                     # Custom CSS styles
â”œâ”€â”€ docs/                          # Output directory for rendered website
â”œâ”€â”€ research_hub.Rproj             # RStudio project file
â”œâ”€â”€ florida-school-analysis.qmd    # Florida Private School Access and Demographics (2000)
â”œâ”€â”€ meeting-dec-05-2025.qmd        # Meeting notes: Dec 5, 2025
â”œâ”€â”€ meeting-dec-09-2025.qmd        # Meeting notes: Dec 9, 2025
â”œâ”€â”€ meeting-dec-12-2025.qmd        # Meeting notes: Dec 12, 2025
â””â”€â”€ jk-instability-dec-05-2025.qmd # JK Instability Analysis




Quarto: Website generation and rendering engine
R: Programming language for computational content
HTML/CSS: Output format with cosmo and brand themes
Git: Version control




The _quarto.yml file contains the main configuration: - Project Type: Website - Output Directory: docs/ (suitable for GitHub Pages) - Theme: Cosmo with brand customizations - Navigation: Home and About pages in navbar - Features: Table of contents enabled





To preview the website locally:
quarto preview
To render the website:
quarto render




Create a new .qmd file in the root directory
Add the page to the navbar in _quarto.yml:
navbar:
  left:
    - href: newpage.qmd
      text: New Page




Quarto Markdown (.qmd) files support: - Markdown formatting - Embedded R code chunks (using {r}) - YAML front matter for page metadata - LaTeX equations - Citations and cross-references






{r}
# Your R code here
plot(1:10)



Edit _quarto.yml:
format:
  html:
    theme: [minty, flatly, cosmo, etc.]



Add CSS rules to styles.css for custom styling.




When creating or editing content for this research hub:



Never use bold formatting (asterisks) in headers or labels
Do not use bold for emphasis in callout boxes
Keep text clean and concise without flowery language
Avoid unnecessary formatting symbols in headers and subheadings




Good:
Topic: Analysis of spending patterns

::: {.callout-note}
The Issue: Data is missing for some counties.
:::

- Finding: Results show significant effects.
Bad:
**Topic:** Analysis of spending patterns

::: {.callout-note}
**The Issue:** Data is missing for some counties.
:::

- **Finding:** Results show significant effects.





Development branches follow the pattern: claude/*-[session-id]
Always commit with descriptive messages
Push changes to the feature branch using: git push -u origin <branch-name>




The rendered website is output to the docs/ directory, which can be: - Served locally for preview - Deployed to GitHub Pages - Hosted on other static site hosting services

title: Never-Treated Jackknife Fixes
text:
This document explains the fixes implemented for the Jackknife Figure 2 issues identified on December 2nd. The core problem was that although all counties received a predicted spending value, only ever-treated counties were assigned a value for the binary indicator high. Never-treated counties were assigned missing values, which caused them to be dropped from regressions even though they should have remained in the sample.
All analyses now incorporate two fixes:

Setting high = 0 for never-treated units

Removing interactions between high and the year effects













FigureÂ 1: Event study estimates by baseline spending quartile













FigureÂ 2: Event study estimates by baseline spending and income quartiles













FigureÂ 3: Event study estimates by baseline spending, income quartiles, and reform types















FigureÂ 4: Jackknife event study estimates - baseline spending only













FigureÂ 5: Jackknife event study estimates - baseline spending and income quartiles













FigureÂ 6: Jackknife event study estimates - full specification with reforms

Patterns Observed

In the non-jackknife regressions, the high group is clearly above the low group.

In the jackknife version, this pattern reverses: the estimated effect for the high group often dips below the low group.

title: Github
text:
Partial replication and extension of Jackson, Johnson, and Persico (2016)


View on GitHub



This repository supports a partial replication and extension of â€œThe Effects of School Spending on Educational and Economic Outcomes: Evidence from School Finance Reformsâ€ by C. Kirabo Jackson, Rucker C. Johnson, and Claudia Persico (2016, QJE). The original study examines how increases in school spending, driven by exogenous timing of court-ordered School Finance Reforms (SFRs), affect long-run educational attainment and adult labor market outcomes, particularly among children from low-income families.
Our work reconstructs the district-level finance panel (F-33 and INDFIN) used in the paper and extends it to county geographies to enable compatibility with proprietary Census data. This involves reprocessing the 1969 GRF (Geographic Reference File) to link school districts with Census tracts and counties, addressing non-tract areas, and implementing aggregation logic for counties with both tract and non-tract zones.



The original JJP (2016) paper and its Online Appendix describe the following key data and methods:
Data Sources:

INDFIN Historical Database (FY 1967,1969â€“1991) â€” standardized local government finances including school districts
Common Core of Data (CCD) NCES F-33 Finance Survey (post-1992 annual continuation)
1969â€“70 School District Geographic Reference File (GRF) for linking Census tracts to pre-reform district geographies

Identification Strategy:

Court-ordered School Finance Reforms (SFRs) serve as exogenous shocks
The number of years of exposure to initial SFR is the treatment variable
Event-study and 2SLS models estimate causal impacts on spending and individual outcomes
Data on court rulings comes from a preceding NBER working paper: https://www.nber.org/papers/w20118

Our Specific Aims:

Develop crosswalks linking F-33 (District) â†”ï¸ INDFIN (District) â†”ï¸ Tract (GRF) â†”ï¸ County (GRF) identifiers
Reconstruct consistent annual per-pupil spending at the county level
Use this data to estimate event studies akin to figure 1 JJP 2016
Extend the analysis with jackknife regressions to identify which counties experienced the largest spending increases from school finance reforms akin to figure 2 in JJP 2016

Coverage:

Time Period: 1967, 1969-2019 (F-33 and INDFIN harmonization)
Geographic Units: 1970 Census tract definitions
Sample Restrictions: Counties with complete baseline data (1967, 1970-1972) for quality analysis

Key Variables:

Spending: pp_exp (nominal), pp_exp_real (2000 dollars), lexp_ma_strict (log spending with 13-year rolling mean)
Population: school_age_pop (used for weighting in aggregation)
Treatment: reform_year (year of court-ordered SFR), relative_year (years since reform)
Quality Flags: good_govid, good_tract, good_county (baseline data completeness)
Baseline Quartiles: pre_q1969, pre_q1970, pre_q1971 (pre-reform spending distribution)

Spatial Matching:

Uses 1970 tract definitions from 1969-70 GRF
Untracted areas assigned residual county characteristics
Single LEAID assigned per tract based on population weights
Counties collapsed from tracts using school-age population weights

Required Software:

Stata (tested with Stata 16+)
Required Stata packages: winsor2, rangestat, eststo/esttab, fred (for CPI data)
Install packages via: ssc install [package_name]




The pipeline follows a sequential process:
Phase I: Data Construction

01_build_district_panel.do - Builds district-year panels from F-33 and INDFIN, creates canonical LEAID â†”ï¸ GOVID crosswalks
02_build_tract_panel.do - Parses 1969 GRF to link districts to Census tracts, assigns single LEAID per tract
03_adjust_inflation.do - Adjusts tract-level spending for inflation using FRED CPI-U data
04_tag_county_quality.do - Tags counties as â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbadâ€ based on baseline year data completeness (1967, 1970-1972)
05_create_county_panel.do - Interpolates district panel, re-assigns to tracts, imports enrollment data, collapses to county-year panel

Phase II: Main Analysis

06_A_county_balanced_figure1.do - County-level event-study analysis (Figure 1 replication)

Creates balanced panel with complete event windows (-5 to +17 years)
Runs weighted event-study regressions by baseline spending quartile
Produces Figure 1 style plots showing dynamic treatment effects

06_B_district_balanced_figure1.do - District-level event-study analysis (Figure 1 replication)

District-level counterpart to county analysis
Uses district panel instead of county aggregation


Phase III: Jackknife

07_jackknife_heterogeneity.do - Leave-one-state-out jackknife to identify treatment effect heterogeneity

Purpose: Identifies which counties experienced larger spending increases from reforms
Method: For each state, estimates treatment effects excluding that stateâ€™s data, then predicts spending increases for excluded state
Panel: Uses balanced panel (complete -5 to +17 event windows)
Outputs:

High vs low predicted spending group comparisons
Quartile analysis showing differential treatment effects



Phase IV: Archived Experiments

experimental_archive/ contains historical robustness checks, alternative specifications, and exploratory analyses




Intermediate Datasets:

districts_panel_canon.dta - District-year panel with quality flags (from 01)
tracts_panel_canon.dta - Tract-year panel with assigned LEAIDs (from 02)
tracts_panel_real.dta - Inflation-adjusted tract panel (from 03)
county_clean.dta - County quality flags (from 04)

Final Analysis Datasets:

interp_d.dta - County-year panel (1967, 1969-2019) with:

Per-pupil spending (nominal and real 2000 dollars)
School-age population weights
Reform exposure variables
Baseline spending quartiles
Quality flags for balanced event-study samples

jjp_interp.dta / jjp_balance.dta - Processed panels for Figure 1 analysis (from 06_A/06_B)
jjp_interp_jk.dta / jjp_balance_jk.dta - Processed panels for jackknife analysis (from 07)
pred_spend_ppe_all_jk.dta - Jackknife predicted spending classifications with:

Predicted spending increase for each county (leave-one-state-out)
High/low treatment group indicators
Quartile classifications
Baseline spending and income quartiles


Analysis Outputs:

Event-study regression estimates
Event-study plots showing dynamic treatment effects
Heterogeneity analysis plots:

High vs low predicted spending group comparisons
Four-quartile differential treatment effects
Combined plots showing treatment effect variation

Jackson, C. K., Johnson, R. C., & Persico, C. (2016). The Effects of School Spending on Educational and Economic Outcomes: Evidence from School Finance Reforms. The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 131(1), 157â€“218.

title: Github
text:
This repository supports a partial replication and extension of â€œThe Effects of School Spending on Educational and Economic Outcomes: Evidence from School Finance Reformsâ€ by C. Kirabo Jackson, Rucker C. Johnson, and Claudia Persico (2016, QJE). The original study examines how increases in school spending, driven by exogenous timing of court-ordered School Finance Reforms (SFRs), affect long-run educational attainment and adult labor market outcomes, particularly among children from low-income families.
Our work reconstructs the district-level finance panel (F-33 and INDFIN) used in the paper and extends it to county geographies to enable compatibility with proprietary Census data. This involves reprocessing the 1969 GRF (Geographic Reference File) to link school districts with Census tracts and counties, addressing non-tract areas, and implementing aggregation logic for counties with both tract and non-tract zones.

title: Github
text:
The original JJP (2016) paper and its Online Appendix describe the following key data and methods:
Data Sources:

INDFIN Historical Database (FY 1967,1969â€“1991) â€” standardized local government finances including school districts
Common Core of Data (CCD) NCES F-33 Finance Survey (post-1992 annual continuation)
1969â€“70 School District Geographic Reference File (GRF) for linking Census tracts to pre-reform district geographies

Identification Strategy:

Court-ordered School Finance Reforms (SFRs) serve as exogenous shocks
The number of years of exposure to initial SFR is the treatment variable
Event-study and 2SLS models estimate causal impacts on spending and individual outcomes
Data on court rulings comes from a preceding NBER working paper: https://www.nber.org/papers/w20118

Our Specific Aims:

Develop crosswalks linking F-33 (District) â†”ï¸ INDFIN (District) â†”ï¸ Tract (GRF) â†”ï¸ County (GRF) identifiers
Reconstruct consistent annual per-pupil spending at the county level
Use this data to estimate event studies akin to figure 1 JJP 2016
Extend the analysis with jackknife regressions to identify which counties experienced the largest spending increases from school finance reforms akin to figure 2 in JJP 2016

title: Research Hub 2.0
text:
Research Timeline
A chronological record of project milestones and findings.


December 2025

December 19: Too few counties
Addressing the issue of states contributing very few counties to the balanced sample, which undermines quartile-based effect interpretation.







Problem: Several states contribute fewer than 4 counties to the balanced sample, making within-state quartiles poorly defined
Solution: Restrict sample to states that are (i) never treated or (ii) ever-treated with 10+ counties meeting balance criteria
Re-ran Fig 1 (county distribution by quartile) and Fig 2 (event studies) with three specifications each:

Specification A: Baseline spending only (pre_q)
Specification B: Baseline spending + Income quartiles (pre_q + inc_q)
Specification C: Baseline spending + Income Ã— Reform Types (pre_q + inc_q*reform_types)

Both baseline and jackknife versions presented for quartile and high vs low comparisons




View Full Meeting Notes



Dec 16: Sample Consistency and Blue-Line County Analysis
Verifying sample consistency between jackknife and non-jackknife specifications, analyzing quartile switching patterns, and characterizing high predicted spending (blue-line) counties.







Confirmed identical samples between Figure 2.1 (non-jackknife) and Figure 2.4 (jackknife) from 12/12 meeting
32.33% of ever-treated counties (150 of 464) switch quartiles after introducing jackknife
Blue-line (Q4) counties are disproportionately low-baseline-spending (47.32% in pre_q=1) and geographically concentrated (44.64% in Alabama)
Baseline spending quartiles 1-2 tend to move to higher predicted spending; quartiles 3-4 tend to move lower




View Full Meeting Notes



Dec 12: Florida Private School Access and Demographics (2000)
Cross-sectional analysis of the relationship between Florida community demographics and private school access for the year 2000.







Geographic Unit: Public Use Microdata Areas (PUMAs)
Distance Buffer: 5-mile radius
Key finding: Non-religious schools show notably different patterns from religious schools, including significant association with higher income areas and college-educated populations
After controlling for demographics, private school count has no significant relationship with area income




View Full Florida Analysis



Dec 12: Good vs Bad Counties and Quartile-Specific Figure 2
Comparing good counties only versus good and bad counties for Fig 1 and event study estimates by quartile for Fig 2.







Fig 1 estimates using 1971 baseline spending quartiles comparing good counties only versus good and bad counties
Summary statistics comparing baseline spending, income, region, and population between good and bad counties
Six specifications showing event study estimates with four lines (one per quartile of predicted spending)

Specification A: Baseline spending only
Specification B: Baseline spending + Income quartiles
Specification C: Baseline spending + Income quartiles + Reform types
Each specification shown with both No Jackknife and Jackknife approaches





View Full Meeting Notes



Dec 09: Baseline vs Jackknife Event Study Results (Latest Figure 2s)
Comparing baseline (no jackknife) and jackknife approaches across three specifications.







Specification A: Baseline spending only
Specification B: Baseline spending + Income quartiles
Specification C: Baseline spending + Income quartiles + Reform types

Each specification includes both full-sample estimates (baseline) and leave-one-state-out jackknife predictions.



View Full Meeting Notes



Dec 05: Never-Treated Jackknife Fixes
Updated Figure 2 plus some notes on fixes.
View Full Meeting Notes



Dec 05: JK Instability - Jackknife Classification Issues
Investigation of jackknife classification instability in Approach II.






Two states (Ohio and Texas) have below-average spending growth for their high-baseline-spending counties. When these states are left out in the jackknife step, their influence disappears, and counties that underperform in the full sample suddenly receive inflated predicted spending values. This pushes them incorrectly into the â€œhigh predictedâ€ category.
840 observations (11.9% of the â€œhighâ€ group) contaminate the jackknife results, compressing the event-study trends.




View JK Instability Analysis




Dec 02: Figure 2 Fixes & Jackknife Strategy
Resolving the â€œNever Treatedâ€ interaction issue.






â€œHighâ€ variable was defined as missing for never-treated units, dropping them from interaction regressions.
Fix: Define high=0 among NTs and remove interaction with year effects (let NTs dictate year effects).



Next Steps (Jackknife Iterations):

Baseline spending only (No Jackknife)
Baseline + Income Quartiles (No Jackknife)
Baseline + Income + Reform Types (No Jackknife)
Repeat 1-3 with Jackknife.


View Jackknife Code Review





November 2025

Nov 25: Robustness & JJP Comparison
Jackknife vs Non-Jackknife and Sample Selection Bias.

Decision: Run Fig 1 among bottom 10% baseline spending counties.
Context (JJP Comparison): JJPâ€™s Figure 1 (large effect) uses PSID-linked districts (~10% of districts, selected for low income). JJP Appendix B2 (all districts) shows smaller effects closer to our findings.

View Analysis



Nov 17-21: District & Panel Analysis
District level expansion and balancing checks.

Balance Exercise: Sample balanced on non-missing lexp_ma_strict from event times -5 to 17.
Hypothesis: Aggregating to county level smooths variation across districts, potentially leading to smaller effects than JJP.


District Level Results Balanced Panel Results




Nov 06: Sample Variations (Fig 1 & 2)
Robustness checks across weighted/unweighted and sample restrictions.

October 2025

Oct 31: The â€œMixedâ€ County Problem
Handling counties with multiple non-tracted areas.






The Issue: We lack school-age population data for non-tracted areas. If a county has >1 non-tracted area, we cannot weight them relative to each other.
The Fix: Combine all non-tracted areas in a county into a single â€œpseudo-area.â€ Average their PPE (unweighted), then weight this pseudo-area against the tracts using the residual county population.






Oct 28: Defining â€œGoodâ€ Counties
Creating a clean baseline dataset.

Definition: A â€œGood Countyâ€ is one where every linked tract/LEAID has non-missing spending data for every year from 1966-1971.
Action: Created indicator variables good_county_6671 to filter samples.




Oct 24: Baseline Year Selection

Findings: 1971 vs.Â 1966-70 average yields similar results.
Decision: Use 1971 on its own or average across several years (robustness check).

View Full Notes



Oct 21: Pre-Quartile Splits

Goal: Compare individual pre-quartile splits (e.g., 1967 vs 1971) to ensure single-year spikes arenâ€™t driving results.

View Full Notes



Oct 17: Interpolation & Winsorizing

Method: Winsorize all spending values at 1st and 99th percentiles (within year).
Refinement: Interpolate at the district level before tract-to-county processing (previously done at tract level).

View Full Notes



Oct 11: Common Core & Balancing

Data Update: Incorporated Common Core spending data through 2018-19.
Balancing: Redefined lead_5 to bin all earlier years; lag_17 bins all later years. Exclude counties treated 2000+.

View Full Notes



Oct 07: Debugging pred_spend

Challenge: Event studies by pred_spend went in opposite directions than expected.
Action: Step-by-step reconstruction (Simple event study â†’ Baseline Quartile split â†’ pred_spend construction).

View Full Notes




September 2025

Sep 30: Reform Variables

Decision: Build pred_spend without reforms to isolate variable issues.

View Full Notes



Sep 23: Wisconsin Binning Fix

Bug: Coefficients for lead 16-19 were empty, but lead 20 was non-empty.
Cause: Binning issue in estimation. Fixed.

View Full Notes



Sep 02: Hanushek vs.Â JJP

Action: Re-run First Stage Approach 1 using only JJP reform info (ignore Hanushek table for now) to ensure replication.

View Full Notes




August 2025

Aug 26: Data Cleaning

Imputation: Imputed 1986 enrollment using 1987 numbers for district 3416800.
Zero Values: For 1983 enrollment==0, replaced with â€™84 (or â€™82) values.




Aug 19: JJP Methodology Deep Dive
Weighting and Rolling Windows.

Difference: JJP uses district-level; we use county-level.
Variable Definitions:

Current year spending (weighted by 1972 pop).
Log average PPE over 13-year rolling window (missing if <13 years data).
Log average PPE over available data (filling missing years with 1967 value).





Aug 01: The PPE Formula
Calculating Per Pupil Expenditures (PPE) for split tracts.






Logic for Primary/Secondary Tracts:

Get Primary PPE and Secondary PPE.
Get share of students in tract who are Primary-age vs Secondary-age.
Formula: (PrimaryPPE * PrimaryShare) + (SecondaryPPE * SecondaryShare)








July 2025

July 29: Duplicate Tracts

Issue: Tracts appearing multiple times (once for elementary, once for secondary).
Resolution: Reshape to tract level with separate variables for elementary/secondary districts.




July 15: Geographic Challenges

Issue: Difficulty mapping districts to counties via tracts.
Strategy: If population weighting fails, default to centroids. Match failures (un-tracted areas) assigned to counties via GRF.




July 11: Project Kickoff

Goal: Produce panel of per-pupil spending at the county level.
Rationale: We only observe birth location at the county level.

title: JK Instability
text:
This memo explains why the jackknife plots sometimes show the â€œhighâ€ group dipping below the â€œlowâ€ group. After applying the fixes Nick flagged on Tuesday, the updated charts look cleaner, but the same core issue remains: the jackknife estimates often compress the â€œhighâ€ group and, in several cases, push it below the â€œlowâ€ group.
The main mechanism is straightforward. Some counties that are classified as low in the full-sample prediction model (because predicted spending < 0) flip into the high category when their own state is excluded from the model during the jackknife procedure. This misclassification is likely not the only problem in the jackknife approach, but it appears to be a major contributor to the pattern we observe.
A closer investigation shows that two states â€” Ohio and Texas â€” have below-average spending growth among counties that should be in the highest-baseline-spending group. When these states are left out in the jackknife step, their influence disappears, and counties that underperform in the full sample suddenly receive inflated predicted spending values. This pushes them incorrectly into the â€œhigh predictedâ€ category.



The goal is simple:

Assign each county a predicted spending change.

Create a binary indicator equal to 1 if predicted spending > 0 and 0 otherwise (for ever-treated counties).

Run an event-study regression using that binary variable.

Under normal circumstances, this should yield the intuitive ordering: high above low.





To keep things simple, consider the specification that controls only for baseline 1971 spending quartile. In the baseline approach, we use the full sample and regress expenditure on quartile indicators. This produces predicted spending values, which we then use to define high (predicted > 0). Running an event-study with this high variable delivers the expected pattern: high consistently exceeds low.








FigureÂ 1: Event study estimates by baseline spending quartile







The jackknife repeats the same regression multiple times, each iteration excluding one state. For each iteration, we:

Re-estimate the model without state s.

Generate predicted spending for counties in the omitted state.

Assign those counties to high/low based on the jackknife prediction.

Move on to the next state.

The advantage is that no single state can dominate the prediction model. The problem is that when we use these jackknife-based predictions to create the high variable for the second-stage event study, we sometimes obtain the reverse ordering: the low group sits above the high group.








FigureÂ 2: Event study estimates by baseline spending and income quartiles



Ordinarily I would assume this pattern reflects a coding mistake, because mechanically the high group should exceed the low group. But after checking the underlying data more closely, that explanation doesnâ€™t hold.
Tabulating pre_q Ã— high (baseline spending quartile Ã— high/low classification) shows the issue clearly:



Quartile
Regular High
Jackknife High
Difference




pre_q 1
3,080
3,080
0


pre_q 2
3,136
3,136
0


pre_q 3
0
504
+504


pre_q 4
0
336
+336


Total
6,216
7,056
+840



Finding: 840 counties from pre_q 3 and pre_q 4 (the highest-baseline-spending groups) switch from â€œlowâ€ to â€œhighâ€ under the jackknife. These are units that should theoretically have lower predicted spending changes, not higher.






To understand the flips, we compare the coefficients that form predicted spending in the full sample versus the jackknife runs for Ohio and Texas. Predicted spending equals the main effect plus the quartile adjustment relative to quartile 1 (main + ppe). Here, ppe3 and ppe4 refer to the coefficients on lag_*#pre_q3 and lag_*#pre_q4.


Full Sample - main = 0.0208505
- ppe3 = âˆ’0.0227245
- ppe4 = âˆ’0.0299217
Ohio Omitted - main = 0.0138311
- ppe3 = âˆ’0.0193518
- ppe4 = âˆ’0.0120878
Texas Omitted - main = 0.0248799
- ppe3 = âˆ’0.0052331
- ppe4 = âˆ’0.0299885




When Ohio is excluded, ppe4 rises from âˆ’0.0299217 to âˆ’0.0120878 (+0.0178339).
This boosts quartile-4 predicted spending enough to flip 336 quartile-4 counties into the high group.
When Texas is excluded, ppe3 rises from âˆ’0.0227245 to âˆ’0.0052331 (~+0.0174914).
This raises quartile-3 predicted spending, flipping 504 quartile-3 counties into the high group.

Together, these shifts generate 840 additional â€œhigh predictedâ€ classifications that only appear under the jackknife. This inflates the size of the high group with counties that actually exhibit weak spending growth, which pulls down the average effect for the high group and produces the inversion seen in the jackknife plots.

title: Florida Private School Access and Demographics: 2000 Analysis
text:
This document presents cross-sectional analysis of the relationship between Florida community demographics and private school access for the year 2000. The analysis examines PUMA-level demographic characteristics (income, race, ethnicity, education) and their association with private school exposure measures within a 5-mile radius.
Key Features:

Geographic Unit: Public Use Microdata Areas (PUMAs)
Distance Buffer: 5-mile radius (primary specification)
School Levels: Elementary, middle, and high school combined
Time Period: Year 2000 Census cross-section







Methodology Note



School exposure measures are constructed at the Census block level using geocoded school coordinates, then aggregated to PUMA geography. Demographic measures come from IPUMS 2000 Census 5% sample.

title: Florida Private School Access and Demographics: 2000 Analysis
text:
This document presents cross-sectional analysis of the relationship between Florida community demographics and private school access for the year 2000. The analysis examines PUMA-level demographic characteristics (income, race, ethnicity, education) and their association with private school exposure measures within a 5-mile radius.
Key Features:

Geographic Unit: Public Use Microdata Areas (PUMAs)
Distance Buffer: 5-mile radius (primary specification)
School Levels: Elementary, middle, and high school combined
Time Period: Year 2000 Census cross-section







Methodology Note



School exposure measures are constructed at the Census block level using geocoded school coordinates, then aggregated to PUMA geography. Demographic measures come from IPUMS 2000 Census 5% sample.

Variable Definitions (Percent vs.Â Proportion Explicit)




Percent Units (0â€“100 scale)
These variables are already expressed in percentage points.

hisp_share: Percent Hispanic

black_share: Percent Black

white_share: Percent White



Proportion Units (0â€“1 scale)
Multiply by 100 to interpret as percent.

less_hs: Share with less than high school

hs_grad: Share with high school diploma

some_college: Share with some college

college_plus: Share with a college degree or higher



Raw Continuous Variables
No scaling.

avg_income: Average household income (2000 dollars)

avg_age: Mean age

total_school: Count of private schools within 5 miles

relig / non_relig: Counts of religious vs.Â non-religious schools

distinct_fine: Number of distinct fine-grained school types

distinct_collapsed: Number of distinct collapsed school categories

Interpretation Guide



This regression answers: â€œAfter controlling for race, ethnicity, age, and education, do areas with more private schools have higher incomes?â€

total_school coefficient (58.16, n.s.): After controlling for demographics, private school count has no significant relationship with area income
hs_grad coefficient (-224,711*):** Areas with higher shares of residents whose highest education is high school (vs.Â less or more) have dramatically lower incomes
hisp_share coefficient (-244*):** Higher Hispanic population share associated with lower average income, controlling for other factors
avg_age coefficient (928*):** Older populations associated with higher income areas
R-squared (0.624): Demographics explain 62% of income variation across PUMAs

title: Florida Private School Access and Demographics: 2000 Analysis
text:
Key Findings
Based on these results:

No Income Sorting on Total Schools: Neither total schools nor religious schools show significant correlation with income. Only non-religious schools are located in higher-income areas.
Racial/Ethnic Patterns: All school exposure measures are positively correlated with Black and Hispanic population shares. Areas with more private schools tend to be more racially diverse.
Education Correlation: Areas with more schools (especially non-religious) have fewer residents with only high school education and more college graduates.
Religious vs.Â Non-Religious Differences:

Non-religious schools: Associated with higher income, higher Hispanic share, higher college attainment
Religious schools: No income relationship, but associated with racial diversity and lower educational attainment

Multivariate Results: After controlling for demographics, school count has no independent relationship with income. Education (hs_grad) and ethnicity (hisp_share) are the strongest predictors.

title: Florida Private School Access and Demographics: 2000 Analysis
text:
This document presents cross-sectional analysis of the relationship between Florida community demographics and private school access for the year 2000. The analysis examines PUMA-level demographic characteristics (income, race, ethnicity, education) and their association with private school exposure measures within a 5-mile radius.
Key Features:

Geographic Unit: Public Use Microdata Areas (PUMAs)
Distance Buffer: 5-mile radius (primary specification)
School Levels: Elementary, middle, and high school combined
Time Period: Year 2000 Census cross-section







Methodology Note



School exposure measures are constructed at the Census block level using geocoded school coordinates, then aggregated to PUMA geography. Demographic measures come from IPUMS 2000 Census 5% sample.
